abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: In this article, we study short intervals that contain another type of “almost square”, an integer n which can be factored in two different ways n=⁢a1b1=⁢a2b2 with a1a2b1b2 close to n.

para.p: In [], the author studied the problem of finding “almost squares” in short intervals, namely:

p.text: For 0≤θ</12, what is the least ⁢fθ such that, for some >c1c20, any interval -x⁢c1x⁢fθ+x⁢c1x⁢fθ contains an integer n with =n⁢ab, where a, b are integers in the interval -x/12⁢c2xθ+x/12⁢c2xθ? Note: c1 and c2 may depend on θ.

para.p: A similar question is the following:

p.text: For 0≤θ</12, what is the least ⁢gθ such that, for some >c1c20, any interval -x⁢c1x⁢gθ+x⁢c1x⁢gθ contains an integer n with n=⁢a1b1=⁢a2b2, where a1<a2≤b2<b1 are integers in the interval -x/12⁢c2xθ+x/12⁢c2xθ? Note: c1 and c2 may depend on θ.

para.p: Note: Actually, the author first considered Question and then turned to Question which has connection to the problem on the distribution of ⁢n2α1mod and the problem on gaps between sums of two squares.
In [], we showed that =⁢fθ/12 when 0≤θ</14, =⁢f/14/14 and ≥⁢fθ-/12θ. We conjectured that =⁢fθ-/12θ for /14<θ</12 and gave conditional result when /14<θ</310. To Question , we have the following

p.text: For 0<θ</14, ⁢gθ does not exist (i.e. all possible products of pairs of integers in -x/12⁢c2xθ+x/12⁢c2xθ are necessarily distinct for large x).

para.p: We believe that the lower bound is closer to the truth and conjecture

Suppose n=⁢a1b1=⁢a2b2 with -x/12⁢c2xθ≤a1<a2≤b2<b1≤+x/12⁢c2xθ. Let =d1a1a2 and =d2b1b2 be the greatest common divisors. Then we must have >d1d21. For otherwise, say =d11, then a2 divides b1 which implies +x/12⁢c2xθ≥b1≥⁢2a2≥-⁢2x/12⁢2c2xθ. This is impossible for large x as <θ/12. Now, let =a1⁢d1e1, =a2⁢d1e2, =b1⁢d2f1 and =b2⁢d2f2. Here e1e2=1=f1f2. Then
Due to co-primality, =e2f1 and =e1f2. Therefore,
with 1<d1<d2, <e1e2 and =e1e21.

Now, from ≤-a2a1⁢2c2xθ, d1≤-⁢d1e2⁢d1e1≤⁢2c2xθ. Similarly, one can deduce that ≤d2e1e2⁢2c2xθ. Moreover, as ⁢d1e1=a1≥-x/12⁢c2xθ, we have ≥d1e1-⁢1⁢2c2x-/12θ12. Similarly, ≥d2e2-⁢1⁢2c2x-/12θ12. Summing up, we have

Math.text: formulae@((1 / (2 * c _ 2)) * x ^ (1 / 2 - theta) - 1 / 2 less= list@(d _ 1, d _ 2, e _ 1), e _ 2 less= 2 * c _ 2 * x ^ theta)

para.p: From (), we see that no such n exists for 0≤θ</14 and hence Theorem .
From () and (), we see that an integer n=⁢a1b1=⁢a2b2, satisfying the conditions for a1a2b1b2 in Question , must be of the form:

Math.text: formulae@(n = d _ 1 * e _ 1 * d _ 2 * e _ 2 * [ with ] * (1 / (2 * c _ 2)) * x ^ (1 / 2 - theta) - 1 / 2 less= d _ 1, list@(d _ 2, e _ 1, e _ 2) less= 2 * c _ 2 * x ^ theta)

para.p: and -x/12⁢c2xθ≤⁢d1e1<⁢d1e2⁢d2e1<⁢d2e2≤+x/12⁢c2xθ. In particular, ≤-⁢e2d2⁢e2d1⁢2c2xθ which implies ≤-e2e1/⁢2c2xθd2. Similarly, ≤-d2d1/⁢2c2xθe2. Thus, the number of such quartuple d1d2e1e2 is bounded by

for any >ϵ0 as the number of divisor function ≪⁢dnnϵ. It follows that there are at most ⁢Ox+-⁢3θ/12ϵ such integers n in the interval -x/⁢c2x+/12θ3+x/⁢c2x+/12θ3. Therefore, some two consecutive such n’s have gap

Pick y to be the midpoint between these two integers. Then, for some constant >c0, the interval -y⁢cy-1⁢2θϵ+y⁢cy-1⁢2θϵ does not contain any integer n=⁢a1b1=⁢a2b2 with -y/12/⁢c2yθ2≤a1<a2≤b2<b1≤+y/12/⁢c2yθ2 as -x/⁢c2x+/12θ3≤y≤+x/⁢c2x+/12θ3. Consequently, for any constant >cc′0, there is arbitrarily large y such that the interval -y⁢cy-1⁢2θ⁢2ϵ+y⁢cy-1⁢2θ⁢2ϵ does not contain any integer n=⁢a1b1=⁢a2b2 with -y/12⁢c′yθ≤a1<a2≤b2<b1≤+y/12⁢c′yθ. Therefore, ≥⁢gθ-1⁢2θ⁢2ϵ which gives Theorem by letting →ϵ0.
Proof of Theorem : For any large x, set =Nx/14 and =ξx/14, the integer part and fractional part of x/14 respectively. Based on (), we are going to pick, for 0≤ϵ≤/12,

Math.text: formulae@(d _ 1 = q * N + r _ 1, formulae@(d _ 2 = q * N + r _ 2, formulae@(e _ 1 = (N + s _ 1) / q, e _ 2 = (N + s _ 2) / q)))

para.p: for some 1≤q≤Nϵ, ≤0r1<r2N and ≪s1s2q with N≡-s1≡-s2qmod. Our goal is to make

Math.text: x = (N + xi) ^ 4 = N ^ 4 + 4 * N ^ 3 * xi + O * N ^ 2 approximately-equals (q * N + r _ 1) * ((N + s _ 1) / q) * (q * N + r _ 2) * ((N + s _ 2) / q)

para.p: The right hand side above is
By Dirichlet’s Theorem on diophantine approximation, we can find integer 1≤q≤Nϵ such that

Math.text: absolute-value@(4 * xi - p / q) less= 1 / (q * N ^ epsilon)

para.p: for some integer p. Fix such a q. Then, pick s1<s2<0 to be the largest two integers such that N≡-s1≡-s2qmod. Clearly, ≪s1s2q. Then, one simply picks some 0<r1<r2≪q2 such that =++r1r2qs1s2pq. With these values for qr1r2s1s2, () is

Math.text: absent = N ^ 4 + 4 * N ^ 3 * xi + O * N ^ (3 - epsilon) + O * q ^ 2 * N ^ 2 + O * q ^ 3 * N + O * q ^ 4

para.p: Hence, we have just constructed an integer =n⁢d1e1d2e2 which is within +⁢ON-3ϵ⁢ON+2⁢2ϵ=+⁢Ox-/34/ϵ4⁢Ox+/12/ϵ2=⁢Ox-/34/ϵ4 from x if ≤ϵ/13. One can easily check that =a1⁢d1e1, =b1⁢d2e2, =a2⁢d1e2 and =b2⁢d2e1 are in the interval -x/12⁢Cx+/14/ϵ4+x/12⁢Cx+/14/ϵ4 for some constant >C0. Set =θ+/14/ϵ4. We have, for some >C′0, n=⁢a1b1=⁢a2b2 in the interval -x⁢C′x-1θ+x⁢C′x-1θ such that <a1a2<b2b1 are integers in -x/12⁢Cxθ+x/12⁢Cxθ provided /14≤θ≤+/14/112=/13. This proves Theorem .

Conjecture may be too hard to prove in the moment. As a starting point, can one show that =⁢g/14/12? Or even <⁢g/14/34? Another possibility would be trying to get some results conditionally like []. Also, one may consider ⁢gθ when θ is near to /12. This leads to the problem about gaps between integers that have more than one representation as a sum of two squares.
